Background.text:
Hypercortisolism producing an array of non-specific symptoms
[1]
Exclude exogenous glucocorticoids and pregnancy
Called "Cushing disease" if caused by pituitary tumor

Clinical_Features.text:
Cardiovascular:
Hypertension
Cutaneous: easy bruising, friable, striae,
hyperpigmentation
, poor wound healing
Endocrine
Androgen excess causing hirsutism, amenorrhea, oily skin, increased libido
Glucose intolerance
Obesity
Metabolic: progressive
obesity
(esp. buffalo hump and supraclavicular fat pads obscuring clavicles)
Musculoskeletal: proximal muscle atrophy,
weakness
, osteoporosis
Ophthalmologic: cataracts, increased
intraocular pressure
Psychologic: emotional lability, depression, irritability, anxiety, panic attacks, mild paranoia and mania

Differential_Diagnosis.text:
Iatrogenic
Pituitary adenoma
Adrenal tumor
Adrenal hyperplasia
Ectopic ACTH secretion

Evaluation.text: Outpatient: 24h urinary free cortisol or dexamethasone suppression test

Management.text:
Treat complications (e.g.
hyperglycemia
) as appropriate
Typically outpatient/non-ED management
